prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2060_Chiron
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Thermal flux with band 7 centred at 344 GHz, continuum mode, of the Centaur 2060 Chiron. This proposal asks for continuum observations of 4 Centaurs and 2 TNOs at 344 GHz with the aim of investigating their thermal properties at sub-mm wavelength, and in particular study the emissivity effects. We require a continuum sensitivity of 50 microJy/b to reach a S/N ratio higher than 8-10 even in the worst prediction of the flux values. The flux at 344 GHz is estimated from the best thermal model that fit the available Spitzer and Herschel observations considering a constant emissivity of 0.9 . As emissivity must be lower at 344 GHz, the given flux values must be considered as the maximum expected ones. Indeed, the emissivity may vary from a minimum expected value of 0.3 (worse case, the given expected fluxes must be divided by 3) up to 0.9. In Table 1 of the scientific justification section we give the maximum and minimum S/N ratio obtained assuming respectively an expected flux calculated with an high emissivity of 0.9 and a low emissivity of 0.3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity : for each of our targets we ask for a continuum sensitivity of 50 microJy/beam. This sensitivity is needed in order to reach a good S/N ratio (> 8-10) in the proposed band even in the case the emissivity has a very low value (0.3) at 344 GHz. A S/N > 8-10 will allow to study the thermal inertia and emissivity of the targets with an unprecedented precision (10% or higher). The fluxes in the ALMA bands are estimated on the basis of the thermal model that best fits the Herschel PACS and SPIRE photometry of the proposed targets (see Fornasier et al., 2013, A&A 555, A15, for details on the Herschel fluxes and results on diameter, albedo, emissivity and thermal properties)
Imaging requirements: the typical KBOs apparent diameter are < 0.03", and will not be spatially resolved by any of the available array configuration. Our observations can be performed will all configurations.
Correlator setup: we use the default correlator setup for continuum observations with double polarization. The expected bandwidth is 2 x 7.5 GHz.
Time constraints: there are no time constraints for our observations.
Solar System objects specific: all the proposed targets have accurate ephemeris, that must be updated from the JPL's HORIZONS ephemeris system at the time of observations. Our team includes experts in mm-wave interferometric solar system observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 54598 Bienor
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Thermal flux with band 7 centred at 344 GHz, continuum mode, of the Centaur 54598 Bienor. This proposal asks for continuum observations of 4 Centaurs and 2 TNOs at 344 GHz with the aim of investigating their thermal properties at sub-mm wavelength, and in particular study the emissivity effects. We require a continuum sensitivity of 50 microJy/b to reach a S/N ratio higher than 8-10 even in the worst prediction of the flux values. The flux at 344 GHz is estimated from the best thermal model that fit the available Spitzer and Herschel observations considering a constant emissivity of 0.9 . As emissivity must be lower at 344 GHz, the given flux values must be considered as the maximum expected ones. Indeed, the emissivity may vary from a minimum expected value of 0.3 (worse case, the given expected fluxes must be divided by 3) up to 0.9. The fluxes in the ALMA bands are estimated on the basis of the thermal model that best fits the Herschel PACS and SPIRE photometry of the proposed targets (for Bienor a diameter of 198+/-7km and albedo of 4.3+/-1.5% has been determined by Duffard et al. 2013, A&A submitted)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 38628 Huya
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Thermal flux with band 7 centred at 344 GHz, continuum mode, of the resonant TNOs 38628 Huya (it is in the 3:2 resonance with Neptune, also called a plutino). This proposal asks for continuum observations of 4 Centaurs and 2 TNOs at 344 GHz with the aim of investigating their thermal properties at sub-mm wavelength, and in particular study the emissivity effects. We require a continuum sensitivity of 50 microJy/b to reach a S/N ratio higher than 8-10 even in the worst prediction of the flux values. The flux at 344 GHz is estimated from the best thermal model that fit the available Spitzer and Herschel observations considering a constant emissivity of 0.9 . Indeed, the emissivity may vary from a minimum expected value of 0.3 (worse case, the given expected fluxes must be divided by 3) up to 0.9. In Table 1 of the scientific justification section we give the maximum and minimum S/N ratio obtained assuming respectively an expected flux calculated with an high emissivity of 0.9 and a low emissivity of 0.3.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 136472 Makemake
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Thermal flux with band 7 centred at 344 GHz, continuum mode, of the dwarf planet 136472 Makemake, that is a classical TNO methan rich and with high albedo. This proposal asks for continuum observations of 4 Centaurs and 2 TNOs at 344 GHz with the aim of investigating their thermal properties at sub-mm wavelength, and in particular study the emissivity effects. We require a continuum sensitivity of 50 microJy/b to reach a S/N ratio higher than 8-10 even in the worst prediction of the flux values. The flux at 344 GHz is estimated from the best thermal model that fit the available Spitzer and Herschel observations considering a constant emissivity of 0.9 . As emissivity must be lower at 344 GHz, the given flux values must be considered as the maximum expected ones. Indeed, the emissivity may vary from a minimum expected value of 0.3 (worse case, the given expected fluxes must be divided by 3) up to 0.9. In Table 1 of the scientific justification section we give the maximum and minimum S/N ratio obtained assuming respectively an expected flux calculated with an high emissivity of 0.9 and a low emissivity of 0.3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Transneptunian Objects (TNOs) are bodies populating the Kuiper Belt and they are believed to retain the most pristine material of the Solar System. The Kuiper Belt is the source of the Centaurs, bodies with unstable orbits located between Jupiter and Neptune. ALMA will be able to detect hundreds of them, but a key parameter to interpret the measurements is the unknown submm/mm emissivity. We aim to investigate in band 7 four Centaurs (Chiron, Chariklo, Bienor and 2002 GZ32), and two TNOs (Makemake and Huya), for which we already have observations in the thermal far-infrared range from Spitzer and Herschel. These data clearly indicate a decrease of the objects emissivity for wavelengths > 250/350 microns. The ALMA observations at 344 GHz will allow us to complete the wavelength coverage and to build an unique dataset to investigate TNOs and Centaurs thermal properties and in particular the emissivity effects and their physical causes. Our target sample includes different dynamical classes and physical properties/surface compositions. This study will provide a foundation for interpreting thermal emission from TNOs in the submm, and help to guide future studies of TNOs with ALMA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: This program is complementary to a proposal (PI A. Moullet) focusing on 2 KBO binary (Haumea, Orcus) and requiring the extended configuration with high spatial resolution to separate and measure their satellites. This program will also provide emissivity results for these 2 objetcs, results that will be used in out study.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Astronomy , Arizona, University of
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
